awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RNA processing in trypanosome mitochondria
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study a unique mechanism of gene expression in ancient single-celled parasites called trypanosomes. Unlike most organisms that use the RNA copied from DNA "as is" for directing protein synthesis, in the energy-generating mitochondria of trypanosomes (and other organisms), the RNA is edited by addition or removal of specific information. Why editing occurs is not clear, but understanding how it happens may provide important clues about the function of this type of genetic alteration. The project will have broad educational impact by providing interdisciplinary training opportunities for postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.  In addition, specific efforts will target students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines.  

This project focuses on the process of RNA editing in the mitochondria of trypanosomes. Through the action of a central editing enzyme, called RECC, uridylates are inserted or deleted at thousands of specific sites in dozens of mRNAs. This extensive editing process is directed by hundreds of small non-coding guide RNAs and involves several auxiliary factors. However, the mechanistic basis of the regulation of editing remains a long-standing question in trypanosomal RNA biology. In previous work, a regulatory editing subcomplex, called REH2C, was identified and found to contain three protein subunits.  Two of these, a helicase and a zinc-finger protein, appear to participate directly in editing. A combination of genetic, biochemical, bioinformatics, and proteomic approaches will be used to address how these proteins assemble with mRNAs and guide mRNAs into editosome complexes in vivo and how the complexes carry out editing functions. These studies may establish new paradigms in RNA editing regulation. In a broader sense, the studies will allow a better understanding of how this amazing process evolved. This system can be used to draw analogies with related RNA helicases and RNA processes that are directed by small guide RNAs and that evolved more recently in eukaryotic lineages.

por.por_cntn:
Kinetoplastids, such as trypanosomes, are among the most ancient eukaryotic lineages and include several biological paradigms, e.g., antigenic variation and U-insertion/deletion (U-indel) RNA editing. The astonishing U-indel editing in T. brucei, remodels the mitochondrial mRNome using hundreds of anti-sense guide RNAs (gRNAs). The U-indels progress 3?-to-5? in overlapping blocks directed by gRNAs, to create an open reading frame. This process converts cryptic primary transcripts into mature translatable sequences and regulates mitochondrial physiology. However, only a few molecules are fully edited at steady-state, while most carry partial ?incorrect? edits. U-indel editing is considered highly error-prone and energetically ?wasteful?. The molecular mechanisms enabling minimal editing fidelity for mitochondrial biogenesis remain poorly understood. The current project described the first identified factor that controls editing fidelity.

 

U-indel editing occurs in a molecular machine ?the editosome? with ~40 nuclear-encoded proteins mostly in three complexes that associate with each other via RNA: RNA Editing Catalytic Complex (RECC), RNA Editing Substrate Binding Complex (RESC), and RNA Editing Helicase 2 Complex (REH2C). RESC supports mRNA-gRNA hybrid assembly and action by RECC and REH2C. The RESC complex organization is not completely understood, but it contains gRNA and ~14 protein subunits. RECC catalyzes endonucleolytic cleavage, U-indels, and ligation. REH2C was discovered in our lab, and this NSF-funded project provided the earliest characterization of this complex.

 

Trypanosomes undergo a complex life-cycle with insect and mammalian hosts. Our early studies of REH2C are in insect-stage procyclic trypanosomes, which grow efficiently in axenic cultures and generate plenty of material. Our main Objective were: 1: Characterize the novel REH2C: identification of subunits and validation of direct association in the complex and editing function; 2: Characterize REH2C determinants for assembly in editosomes; 3: Study editing progression in purified editing complexes.

 

Overall, our main findings can be divided in three general sections that have led to new studies currently in progress:

 

First identified editing proteins that control U-indel fidelity. Purified native REH2C includes three proteins, ATP-dependent 3?-5? dsRNA unwinding activity, and associated editing mRNA substrates and products. Thus, REH2C is an mRNP. Two REH2C subunits, KREH2 and KH2F1, function in editing and were shown to bind to each other in recombinant form. KREH2 is the sole DEAH-Box RNA helicase in editosomes. Spliceosomes use several DEAH-Box and DEAD-Box helicases. KH2F1 has 8-zinc fingers and is unusual because DEAH-Box helicases typically bind a G-patch protein cofactor. The KREH2?KH2F1 pair may provide a novel system of helicase control with KH2F1 replacing a G-patch protein. We found that REH2C controls editing fidelity in RESC-associated mRNA, and combined novel bioinformatics with base-resolution RNA-seq in these studies. The effects of REH2C on fidelity were site-specific and substrate-specific. Furthermore, the first few edits by the initiating gRNA (gRNA-1) were generally very accurate in these mRNAs. However, one or more dominant single events of ?incorrect? editing, also affected by REH2C, paused editing initiation.

 

First functional trans effects between physically distinct editing complexes. All prior reports of RNA editing, including from our lab, examined the phenotypes of editing proteins on total RNA from extracts. We reported the first examples of functional trans effects in physically distinct complexes, i.e., how REH2C affects editing of native RESC complex-bound mRNA. We showed that RESC is enriched of editing substrates and products. Our RNA-seq studies of purified native complexes provide more refined information on functional crosstalk and synergy between editing components.

 

Determinants for assembly of REH2C in editosomes and validation of helicase function. Most editing proteins in ancient trypanosomes lack recognizable motifs. However, the REH2C subunits have conserved domains of unknown function. We delineated determinants for KREH2 and KH2F1 stability and assembly into REH2C or for assembly of REH2C into editosomes. Mutation of conserved oligonucleotide binding (OB)-fold residues in KREH2 and other eukaryotic DEAH-Box helicases, including in X-chromosome activation and mRNA splicing, disrupted REH2C assembly and interactions. However, mutations of the basic fold of individual zinc fingers did not affect the REH2C assembly, so the role of the fingers remains unknown (but we are currently examining this issue). Finally, recombinant KREH2 (240 kDa) is a bona fide RNA helicase with ATP-dependent 3?-5? unwinding activity.

 

To date, this three-year project and no-cost extension during the COVID-19 pandemic has produced seven peer-reviewed publications: two papers in prestigious journals, four reviews on RNA editing, and a book discussing recent discoveries in mitochondrial RNA metabolism in protozoa, plants, and humans by several labs in the USA and abroad. Two additional papers are in preparation. Newly generated edited transcriptome sequences have been made available to the public. During this funding period, our lab trained: two predoctoral students, one research scientist; fifteen undergraduates, including an NSF-REU student; a female visiting professor from Pakistan; and three summer high school students. Cruz-Reyes pioneered and bridged a Mexican-USA crosstalk (UNAM-TAMU) that led to an International Academic-Cooperation agreement. Finally, we reported the results of our studies at multiple conferences.
